problem: Let $\bold{v} = \begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\bold{w} = \begin{pmatrix} 11 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix}$.  Find the area of the parallelogram with vertices $\bold{0}$, $\bold{v}$, $\bold{w}$, and $\bold{v} + \bold{w}$.
solution: The area of the parallelogram is given by $|5 \cdot (-2) - 11 \cdot (-3)| = \boxed{23}.$
model_solution:
To find the area of the parallelogram, we need to find the determinant of the 2x2 matrix formed by the vectors $\bold{v}$ and $\bold{w}$. 

The determinant can be calculated as:

$\begin{vmatrix} 5 & 11 \\ -3 & -2 \end{vmatrix}$
To find the determinant, we multiply the diagonal elements and subtract the product of the other two elements: 

$\begin{vmatrix} 5 & 11 \\ -3 & -2 \end{vmatrix} = (5)(-2) - (11)(-3)$
Multiply the diagonal elements and subtract the product of the other two elements: 

$(5)(-2) - (11)(-3) = -10 + 33$
$-10 + 33 = 23$.
The area of the parallelogram is the absolute value of the determinant. 

$|\begin{vmatrix} 5 & 11 \\ -3 & -2 \end{vmatrix}| = |23| = 23$
The area of the parallelogram is the absolute value of the determinant.

$|\begin{vmatrix} 5 & 11 \\ -3 & -2 \end{vmatrix}| = |23| = 23.$
The area of the parallelogram is the absolute value of the determinant, which we have found to be 23.
Since the determinant has been found and its absolute value represents the area of the parallelogram, the problem is now solved. 

$\boxed{23}$
